results.title: The Squatter's Daughter
results.brief_description: In his second feature production, Ken Hall retained little but the title of the old play by Bailey and Duggan which had been more faithfully filmed in 1910. Hall’s film focussed on the rivalry between two sheep stations, one managed by a strong willed woman, Joan Enderby and the other by a weak willed enemy, Clive Sherrington. Hall believed in providing light relief in his dramas and the film introduced some of his most effective comedy sequences. Strong nationalistic sentiment pervades the film, with Frank Hurley’s photography of the outback capturing some vistas of impressive grandeur. Cast includes Jocelyn Howarth, Dick Fair, John Warwick, Fred MacDonald.
results.description:

Hall believed in providing light relief in his dramas and the film introduced some of his most effective comedy sequences. Strong nationalistic sentiment pervades the film, with Frank Hurley’s photography of the Outback capturing some vistas of impressive grandeur.

Cast includes Jocelyn Howarth, Dick Fair, John Warwick, Fred MacDonald.

results.title: The Spy who loved me (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Albert R. Broccoli, United Artists Corporation, Lewis Gilbert and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: The Spy who loved me was the third performance by Roger Moore as James Bond, British secret service agent 007. In this instalment Bond is sent to foil Karl Stromberg - a megalomaniac villain who steals the plans to a nuclear tracking device that will allow him to control missiles and rule the world. Bond is sent to Cairo and teams with sexy Russian agent Anya Amasova (Barbara Bach), fending off seductive women and murderous men, in an attempt to retrieve the microfilm. Famous sequences include the pre-credits ski hill chase and a thrilling pursuit through Cairo that turns into an underwater adventure thanks to some deft British technology. Stromberg’s underwater headquarters make an impressive set piece, and provides ample opportunities for him to feed enemies to man-eating sharks. Richard Kiel stars as Jaws - a memorably gruesome Bond enemy with menacing metal choppers for weaponry. This Bond is replete with impressive stunts, action sequences and wisecracks from the wry lady’s man, but is less campy than its predecessors, “Live and let die” and “The Man with the golden gun”, both of which starred Moore.

results.title: The Spy who came in from the cold
results.creator_credit: Salem Films, Paramount Pictures and Martin Ritt
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by famed writer John Le Carre, Richard Burton plays a spy who is unwilling to “come in from the cold” to assume a desk job. Burnt out, he takes on the most dangerous job of his career, stalking a dangerous East German agent played by Oskar Werner. Full of crosses and double crosses, this is a brilliant espionage thriller. The quality performances by Burton, Werner and Claire Bloom are matched by a tension-packed and well-scripted screenplay. The harsh black and white camera work makes a powerful statement about the futility of the Cold War.

results.title: The Spruce bog: an essay in ecology
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, J.V. Durden, Guy Glover and Dalton Muir
results.brief_description: Describes the conditions under which a spruce bog is formed, with details of the plant types found at successive stages of development from open water to mature spruce forest. Time-lapse photography illustrates the growth and decay of vegetation preceding the appearance of sphagnum moss which chokes off water to make the floor of the forest. Discusses the commercial use of peat extracted from such bogs, and the value of black spruce to Canada’s pulp industry. Written by J.V. Durden. Photography by Dalton Muir. Editing by J.V. Durden. Music by Robert Fleming. Sound by George Croll. Voice and Narration by Geoffrey Hogwood. (Award: Salerno)

results.title: The Sprint crawl
results.creator_credit: Dr Frank Ryan and Ryan Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Swimming Instruction”.
A close study of the competitive swimming stroke, “the sprint crawl”. With the aid of diagrams and slow-motion photography, the film analyses the action of the arm stroke, the leg kick, the pool-edge turning and the initial diving.

results.title: The Spring and fall of Nina Polanski
results.creator_credit: Kathleen Shannon, Louise Roy, Joan Hutton and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
An animation film depicting the life of a certain Nina Polanski, who could be any woman. She marries amidst much fanfare and photo-snapping, and settles into a domestic routine of cooking, washing dishes, ironing, and babies. Eventually she becomes the very machines she uses every day, until one day she walks into the woods and takes back her old self.
